topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: Node MySQL Database Sample

body.p: This very simple Node.js app displays the text "Executed query "SELECT "Hello World!"".", and then the result of that query: "Hello World". This is a demonstration of the minimum requirements to build an application that can connect to a MySQL database provided by ALS and run queries against it. Use this sample to ensure that you have set up your environment for connecting to and working with MySQL on the Helion Development Platform.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: If you are missing any of these items, you will need to install them.

ul.li: Access to an Application Lifecycle Service (ALS) Cluster
The Helion command-line interface (CLI) must be installed.
Access to the web-based Helion Management Console.

section.title: MySQL
section.p: If the MySQL service is not enabled on your cluster, or if you are not sure, follow these steps:

ol.li: Go to the Administrative console for your ALS cluster. For example: https://api.xx.xx.xx.xx.xip.io, substitute your own cluster's link.
On the Admin tab, click Cluster.
Click Cluster Nodes on the left side of the page.
Click the Settings icon (a gear icon in the upper right corner)
The MySQL check box should be checked. If it is not, check it.

p.note: If a more durable or scalable MySQL database service is needed, configure your ALS cluster to use a database instance or master/slave pair provided by the Database Service. For more information, refer to Using the Database Service and Connecting the Database Service with ALS.

section.p: Click here to access the code repository.

section.title: Deploy the Application
section.p: Application Lifecycle Service clusters that require an upstream HTTP proxy to access the internet will need to be made aware of the proxy. The sample applications require access to the Internet in order to download dependent packages.
Use the Helion client to deploy your app to Helion Development Platform. If you have Eclipse installed, you have the option to use the plugin.

ol.li: Ensure that you are targeting your desired environment. If you are not, executehelion target https://api.xx.xx.xx.xx.xip.io
Ensure that you are logged in to your desired environment. If you are not, executehelion login
If you are not already there, cd to the root directory of the sample.
Deploy the application by using the command:helion push

Accept any default values that you may be prompted for.By default, ALS clusters are configured with two domains (private and public). In some situations the Helion CLI may prompt you to select a target domain. If prompted, select the public domain from the given list (i.e. <app-name>.xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx.xip.io)

section.title: Key Code Snippets
section.p: The first line in this section of the Server.js file shows how to retrieve the connection information for the MySQL instance from the application's environment variables. The connection information is represented using JSON. The rest of the code shown here parses the JSON string that was retrieved, connects to the database, execute a query, and prints the response.

The manifest.yml file is the configuration information used by ALS to set up the environment. The services element instructs ALS how to bind to the MySQL service provided by the ALS cluster to the application.
section.codeblock: --- applications: - name: mysql-node mem: 128M services: ${name}-db: type: mysql

ol.li: Open the Helion Management Console. The Management Console is the web-based administrative interface that can be reached by typing the ALS endpoint URL into a browser window.
If the file push was successful, you should see mysql-node in the list of available applications.
The status of the application should be Started. Click the name of the application to launch it.
In the upper right-hand corner, click View App.

section.title: Key Learnings

ul.li: You need to provide configuration information so that ALS can bind to a MySQL service. Configuration information is contained in the manifest.yml file.
You need to retrieve connection information for MySQL from the application's environment variables, and parse the information into a JDBC compliant connection string.
You interact with and deploy your app using the ALS command line client or the web-based ALS Management Console.
